  • 检察官调查锂、氢交易
  • 科斯塔总理受到相关调查
  • 称自己良心清白，愿意配合调查
  • 总统周四向全国发表讲话

葡萄牙总理安东尼奥·科斯塔周二辞职，数小时前，检察官在调查其政府处理锂矿和氢项目时涉嫌腐败的情况下拘留了他的幕僚长。

检察官称科斯塔是相关调查的目标，他在会见总统马塞洛·雷贝洛·德索萨后在电视声明中宣布了这一决定。

他说他的良心是清白的，但他不会第四次竞选总理。

科斯塔表示：“总理职能的尊严与对他的正直、良好行为的任何怀疑是不相容的，更不用说对他的任何犯罪行为的怀疑。”

现在由总统决定是允许在议会中占多数的科斯塔社会党组建新政府还是解散议会并举行选举。

议会定于本月晚些时候对 2024 年预算法案进行投票。

政治学家阿德利诺·马尔特斯说：“政府突然死亡后不可避免地会举行选举。”里斯本大学的安东尼奥·科斯塔·平托(Antonio Costa Pinto)不排除另一位社会党总理接任，但也表示提前选举是最有可能的选择。

葡萄牙股市下跌约 3%，备受关注的 10 年期政府债券收益率与欧元区基准德国国债收益率之间的差距从周一的 65 个基点扩大至 69 个基点。

调查项目

检察官办公室在周二早些时候的一份声明中表示，作为调查的一部分，有五人被拘留，其中包括科斯塔的幕僚长维托·埃斯卡里亚(Vitor Escaria)，他的办公室以及几座政府大楼都遭到了搜查。

它还表示，基础设施部长若昂·加兰巴（​​Joao Galamba）和环境机构 APA 主席努诺·拉卡斯塔（Nuno Lacasta）是正式嫌疑人，并将出庭接受法官审判。

Galamba 办公室和 APA 没有回复置评请求。

检察官正在调查葡萄牙北部 Barroso 和 Monatelgre 锂矿勘探特许权、锡尼什港氢工厂项目以及当地大型数据中心投资涉嫌腐败和以权谋私的行为。

他们表示，他们已经意识到嫌疑人利用科斯塔的名字和权力来“解锁与交易相关的程序”，最高法院将调查科斯塔在这些交易中可能扮演的角色。

科斯塔表示，他“完全愿意与司法系统合作”。

检察官办公室表示：“这可能是……能够构成渎职罪、政治家主动和被动腐败以及以权谋私罪的事实。”

葡萄牙已知锂储量超过 60,000 吨，被视为欧洲确保更多电池价值链和减少对进口依赖的努力的核心。

APA 今年早些时候批准了当地公司 Lusorecursos 在蒙塔莱格雷提取电池级锂，并批准了总部位于伦敦的 Savannah Resources (SAVS.L)在巴罗佐开发自己的矿山。

路透社联系 Lusorecursos 后未立即发表评论。

萨凡纳在一份声明中表示，正在与调查其部分地点的当局合作，但该公司及其任何员工都不是调查的目标。它补充说，巴罗佐锂项目的工作继续不受阻碍。

对未来的担忧

科斯塔将继续留任，直至总统做出决定。雷贝洛·德索萨于周三召集各政党进行磋商，并于周四召集他的咨询机构国务委员会进行磋商。

自2015年在债务危机和国际救助之后上台以来，科斯塔经历了一段强劲的经济增长时期，其间历届政府消除了预算赤字，减轻了债务负担，因健全的财政政策赢得了欧洲的赞誉。

但科斯塔的最后一个任期始于 2022 年初，当时他的政党在提前选举中出人意料地赢得了绝对多数席位，但他的最后一个任期却因丑闻而受到损害，其中包括 2023 年 1 月围绕国有航空公司 TAP 的争议，导致反对党要求他的政府辞职。

荷兰国际集团(ING)全球宏观主管卡斯滕·布热斯基(Carsten Brzeski)预计，由于葡萄牙在金融市场上的声誉来之不易，因此不会对金融市场产生什么影响。

在里斯本的街道上，很少有人表现出惊讶，但许多人对生活成本不断上升的政治危机表示担忧。

“老实说，我不知道（辞职）是好是坏。一切都颠倒了。（生活成本）越来越差。让我们拭目以待，”62 岁的阿纳贝拉·雷斯 (Anabela Reis) 说。

22 岁的努里亚·科斯塔 (Nuria Costa) 担心这一丑闻会落入极右翼切加党 (Chega) 的手中，该党已经是议会第三大党。

它将西班牙语在线新闻媒体 Pressenza 和总部位于智利的 El Ciudadano 列为传播该材料的主要媒体。Pressenza 的网站称其于 2009 年在意大利米兰成立，自 2014 年起在厄瓜多尔注册。

洛佩兹·奥夫拉多尔说：“当我这么说时，我想非常明确地表明，我们不会破坏与以色列的关系，也不会采取呼吁和平以外的立场。”

“正在发生的一切都非常悲伤、非常痛苦、非常不人道，”他补充道。 “非理性才是主导。我当然支持和平和停火。”

周二在吉达举行会谈的调解人通过沙特国家通讯社 SPA 表示，交战的苏丹军队和准军事快速支援部队（RSF）已承诺放松人道主义援助的运送并实施建立信任措施。

双方自四月份以来一直交战，此前曾同意但随后立即违反了停火协议以及促进援助和保护平民的承诺。

SPA宣布的协议不包括停火，因此预计不会减少战斗。

自上个月双方在沙特阿拉伯、美国和非洲地区伊加特斡旋下重新举行会谈以来，苏丹达尔富尔地区和首都喀土穆的战斗愈演愈烈，造成大量平民伤亡。

周二，双方互相指责对方对喀土穆郊区的贾利炼油厂发生大规模火灾负责。

抵达乍得的难民和目击者还指责无国界医生组织在西达尔富尔州朱奈纳镇重燃血腥种族暴力。无国界医生组织将那里的战斗描述为部落暴力。

SPA发布的声明称，调解员对双方尚未达成停火协议表示遗憾。他们敦促交战各方“将苏丹人民的利益放在第一位，放下武器，并通过谈判结束这场冲突”。

声明称，相反，双方同意与联合国人道主义机构人道协调厅合作，解决人道主义援助准入的障碍，并在军队和无国界医生组织之间建立沟通渠道，缓和煽动性言论。

他们还同意逮捕越狱者。战争开始后不久，前总统奥马尔·巴希尔的伊斯兰政权成员表示，他们是更广泛的越狱行动的一部分。

战争于 4 月 15 日爆发，此前数周，双方因一项整合军队的计划而紧张局势不断升级，该计划是从军事统治向文职民主过渡的一部分。

  • 以色列称军队已抵达“加沙市中心”
  • 没有明确证据表明大规模进城，但以色列发言人并不否认袭击
  • 哈马斯称武装分子对推进的以色列人造成严重损失

以色列周二表示，其部队正在深入加沙城，当地居民表示，坦克部署在郊区，可能会袭击加沙城市中心地带。

以色列国防军南方司令部司令亚龙·芬克尔曼少将在加沙边境附近对记者说：“数十年来，以色列国防军首次在加沙市中心、恐怖主义中心作战。”

“每一天、每时每刻，部队都在消灭武装分子、暴露隧道、销毁武器，并继续向敌方中心推进。”

以色列此前表示，它已经包围了加沙城，该市居住着加沙地带230万人口中约三分之一，并将很快袭击该城，以消灭一个月前袭击以色列边境城镇的哈马斯武装分子。

地面上没有迹象表明以色列军队已大规模深入该市，但军方发言人理查德·赫克特表示，包围部队可能正在对这座城市进行袭击。

当被问及是否发生过此类袭击时，他说：“我不会谈论我们如何在加沙城周围的包围圈内采取行动。我只能说，你们的方向是正确的。”

哈马斯军事部门表示，其武装分子正在对推进的以色列军队造成严重损失和破坏。

无法核实双方的战场主张。

大屠杀之月

根据以色列统计，战争于 10 月 7 日爆发，哈马斯战士冲破包围加沙的围栏，杀害了 1,400 名以色列人（其中大部分是平民），并绑架了 200 多人。此后，以色列对哈马斯控制的加沙地带进行了无情的轰炸，根据当地卫生官员的统计，造成 10,000 多人死亡，其中约 40% 是儿童。

联合国人权事务专员沃尔克·特克在开始对该地区的访问时发表声明说：“整整一个月都是大屠杀、持续的痛苦、流血、破坏、愤怒和绝望。”从埃及过境，这是获得援助的唯一路线。

以色列为居民提供了上午10点至下午2点离开加沙城的窗口。居民称，以色列坦克大多在夜间行动，以色列军队主要依靠空中和炮击为地面推进扫清道路。

军方宣布：“为了您的安全，请抓住下一次机会向南移动，越过加沙干河。”这里指的是一分为二的狭窄沿海地区的湿地。

加沙内政部表示，仍有90万巴勒斯坦人在加沙北部避难，其中包括加沙城。

“这是我一生中最危险的旅行。我们从近距离看到了坦克。我们看到了分解的身体部位。我们看到了死亡，”居民亚当·法耶兹·泽亚拉(Adam Fayez Zeyara)贴出了一张自己在离开加沙城的路上的自拍照。

虽然以色列的军事行动集中在加沙北半部，但南部也受到了攻击。巴勒斯坦卫生官员表示，周二早些时候，以色列对加沙南部城市汗尤尼斯和拉法进行了两次单独的空袭，造成至少 23 人死亡。

Russia's formal withdrawal from a landmark arms treaty on Tuesday is the latest example of the crumbling of the security architecture that was set up to make the world safer at the end of the Cold War.

Arms control pacts in the 1980s and 1990s were a sign of easing tensions and increased trust in East-West relations. Now the opposite is the case: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has brought about the deepest crisis in ties between Moscow and Washington since the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, with the Kremlin describing relations as "below zero".

Here is a list of the most important treaties and their current status.

INTERMEDIATE-RANGE NUCLEAR FORCES (INF) TREATY

US President Ronald Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev agreed in 1987 to scrap an entire category of nuclear weapons by permanently eliminating all missiles with ranges between 500 and 5,500 km (310 and 3,400 miles).

From 2014 onwards, the United States repeatedly accused Russia of deploying a non-compliant missile, which Moscow denied. President Donald Trump said in 2018 that the United States would therefore terminate the agreement, and Washington formally withdrew the following year.

Russia said it too would suspend its INF treaty obligations following the US move.

CONVENTIONAL ARMED FORCES IN EUROPE (CFE) TREATY

Signed by 22 countries in 1990, the treaty set equal limits on the amount of weaponry, including tanks, heavy artillery and combat aircraft, that NATO and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact could deploy between the Atlantic Ocean and the Ural mountains.

Russia formally withdrew on Tuesday but had not actively participated since 2015. Moscow said the US push to enlarge NATO had led to alliance members "openly circumventing" its restrictions; NATO allies condemned Russia's withdrawal and said they would suspend their own treaty obligations.

COMPREHENSIVE NUCLEAR TEST BAN TREATY (CTBT)

The CTBT , agreed in 1996, bans "any nuclear weapon test explosion or any other nuclear explosion" anywhere in the world, with the goal of reducing and ultimately eliminating nuclear weapons. Russia ratified it in 2000 but President Vladimir Putin last week signed a law revoking that decision, arguing that Russia should mirror the position of the United States which has never ratified the pact. Russia says, however, that it will keep supplying data to the treaty's verification regime and will not conduct a nuclear test unless the United States does.

NEW START TREATY

Signed in 2010, the New START treaty caps the number of strategic nuclear warheads that Russia and the United States can deploy. Putin said in February that Russia was suspending its participation, alleging that Washington was using information obtained under the treaty to help Ukraine attack Russian strategic sites. The United States said in June it would stop providing Russia with some notifications required under the treaty, including on its missile and launcher locations, to retaliate for Moscow's "ongoing violations" of the accord.

New START is the last remaining pillar of nuclear arms control between the two countries, and is due to expire in 2026.

  • More than 145,000 sea arrivals in Italy this year
  • Compliance with EU law still to be assessed

Italy's government is hailing as "historic" a plan to send seaborne migrants to Albania, but experts and opposition politicians warn that it could face significant bureaucratic and human rights obstacles.

The move is part of an EU-wide drive to clamp down on irregular immigration. Other countries, including Germany , are toughening their policies, amid negotiations within the bloc to overhaul asylum rules and reduce arrivals.

Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni announced the initiative on Monday with her Albanian counterpart Edi Rama, saying her country would build two centres to host up to 36,000 migrants per year on Albanian soil.

The centres, one on the coast for identification and another inland for detention, would be paid in full by Italy and operate under its jurisdiction, meaning they would be covered by European Union asylum rules.

"Big questions loom over the application of Italian jurisdiction in Albania, as it remains unclear how people on the move could access asylum and exercise their basic rights in a non-EU territory," Susanna Zanfrini of the International Rescue Committee, a humanitarian group, said.

A source in Meloni's office said the deal was sealed during her summer holiday in Albania and was aimed at deterring seaborne migrants, who would no longer be assured of access to EU territory after setting off from North Africa.

"This is a historic achievement. For the first time, a non-EU country will help a member state in handling illegal flows," top Meloni aide and government undersecretary Giovanbattista Fazzolari told daily Corriere della Sera.

COMPLEX PLAN, FAIRLY MODEST OUTCOMES

Experts warn it might be hard for Italian courts to quickly process asylum requests or appeals against detention orders from people hosted in another state, and lengthy procedures could place an unjustified burden on the migrants.

"If people's rights are to be respected, this (plan) looks highly complex and bound to produce fairly modest outcomes," Ennio Codini, a legislation expert at Ismu Foundation, a think-tank specialized in migration issues, told Reuters.

He said that, despite efforts to streamline procedures, asylum requests in Italy remained engulfed in red tape, and warned that failed applicants would be hard to repatriate given the lack of return deals with migrants' home nations.

"Countries (of origin) are not keen to take them back," Codini said.

In the year to date, Italy has repatriated just under 4,000 migrants, while more than 145,000 arrived by sea on its shores. Albania's Rama said migrants would have to go to Italy if they could not be repatriated straight from his country.

Chiara Cardoletti, head of the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR) in Italy, said the Albanian scheme might be acceptable as long as it fully respected the UN Refugee Convention and did not result in Italy shifting asylum responsibilities on to Albania.

"We are not saying these transfer arrangements cannot happen, what we are saying is that they are only appropriate if certain standards are met," she told Reuters.

'GUANTANAMO MADE IN ITALY'

Meloni said the Albanian facilities should be operational in Spring 2024, but the European Commission has yet to say whether the initiative is in line with EU law. A spokesperson said Brussels wanted more details before passing judgement.

The spokesperson added that, based on first information, the Italian plan seemed to be different from a British government bid to send thousands of asylum seekers to Rwanda , which has been mired in the courts since it was agreed.

Christopher Hein, a migration law expert at Rome's Luiss University, said the main difference between Albania and Rwanda was that people in Albania were protected by the European Convention on Human Rights.

"Migrants will be brought straight to Albania without disembarking in Italy, while the British plan applies to people who are already on its soil," Hein noted.

Italian opposition parties have denounced Meloni's plans as a deportation, with Riccardo Magi, a lawmaker with the centrist +Europa group, evoking the notorious extrajudicial camps used by the US in Cuba to detain terrorism suspects.

"The Guantanamo Made in Italy that Giorgia Meloni wants to build in Albania is just another cruel propaganda move," Magi said.

Tears welled in May Hayat's eyes as she stood in silence on an emotional return to the site of an Israeli music festival where she narrowly escaped death in a Hamas attack a month ago.

Hayat, 30, was working as a bartender at the open-air Nova music festival a few kilometres from the Gaza security fence when Hamas gunmen attacked on Oct. 7, killing 260 festival-goers and taking others hostage.

She survived her ordeal by hiding under a stage, smearing a victim's blood on her face and pretending to be dead.

Hayat returned to the venue near Kibbutz Re'im in southern Israel for the first time on Monday, hoping it would help her come to terms with her trauma and unlock the tears that she says have flowed properly only once in the past month.

"If you think they (Hamas) are an organisation acting in self-defence..., they are terrorists, they want us dead, they can't justify any of this, they don't care," Hayat, who lives in Tel Aviv, told Reuters.

"They also killed Arab Israelis here, everyone who lives in Israel is a target to kill," she said.

Warning that "they will eventually reach other countries", she added: "I hope you will wake up before it comes to you."

Hayat is one of many Israelis struggling to come to terms with the events of Oct. 7 that triggered an Israeli military campaign to wipe out Hamas, the Palestinian Islamist movement that rules the Gaza Strip.

Some 1,400 Israelis, mostly civilians, were killed in attacks by Hamas militants on Oct. 7 and more than 200 were abducted, according to Israeli tallies.

Since then, Israeli strikes on Gaza have killed more than 10,000 people, around 40% of them children, according to tallies by health officials there.

ESCAPE

On the day of the attack on the music festival, the gunmen left their victims where they killed them and debris was strewn across the ground. The scene was starkly different on Hayat's return, with all the bodies and much of the debris removed.

Hayat had hoped to find a hole she used as one of her hiding places, but was unable to do so.

She jumped nervously each time she heard a loud noise as she wandered around the venue, and at one point she dived to the ground to take cover after what sounded like rocket fire from Gaza. The brother of a friend of Hayat who was killed in the attack consoled her with a hug.

Although her visit brought tears to her eyes, she wiped them away and did not weep openly.

She said Hamas started firing rockets into southern Israel as young people were dancing at around 6:30 am on Oct. 7. Shooting began when Hamas gunmen arriving from Gaza reached the music festival, some of them on foot, others on motor-bikes.

After hiding in a hole, she and a man were discovered by the gunmen.

"At that time, I was simply talking to God, saying 'There's nothing more I can do, it's in your hands now.' I felt they were going to rape me," she said.

The man who had been with her was shot dead but Hayat said she managed to escape after one of two gunmen holding her took pity on her.

"He simply told me to go as the other terrorist was arguing with him, telling him he wants to murder me, and I could see how they were fighting over whether to kill me or not, and I ran away," she said.

She then hid under a stage.

"While I'm lying under the stage, I see that they're shooting at people to make sure they're all dead," she said. "So the body lying next to me – they shot him in the head - I took the blood and wiped it on my face and I simply lay still...to seem dead."

Her ordeal ended when Israeli soldiers arrived several hours after the Hamas attack began.

"When I heard the army coming...it took me a few minutes to clarify that it was the army I was hearing coming, and then I screamed 'Help!' and they came to get me out," she said.

英国政府周二制定了解决犯罪、促进经济增长和淡化气候变化措施的计划，这是一个毫不掩饰的政治议程，可能是首相里希·苏纳克在选举前的第一次也是最后一次国王演讲。

In an agenda written by the government but delivered by King Charles to lawmakers packed into parliament's ornate House of Lords, Sunak signalled his intent to draw a dividing line with the opposition Labour Party before the vote expected next year.

With Labour running way ahead in the opinion polls, Sunak's team is hoping that his agenda will close the gap by reducing what he says is the burden of Britain's climate change targets on households and by toughening sentences for violent offenders.

There was little new in the King's Speech, more a collection of what Sunak has worked on since becoming prime minister last year on a pledge to bring stability after two leaders of his Conservative party were forced from power in a matter of weeks.

"My government will, in all respects, seek to make long-term decisions in the interests of future generations," Charles, wearing the Imperial State Crown and Robe of State, told a hushed audience of lawmakers in the upper house of parliament.

It was the first time Charles had made the speech as king - though he stood in for his mother Queen Elizabeth months before her death last year - in a ceremony marked by pomp and pageantry which also attracted a loud, if small, anti-monarchy protest outside parliament.

他乘坐盛大的马车游行队伍从白金汉宫抵达议会，然后主持了一场仪式，仪式的一些传统可以追溯到 16 世纪，根据英国不同寻常的宪法行政权力划分，传达政府议程。

竞选

The largely domestic focus of the plans Charles read out suggested Britain has already entered campaign season, with Labour, even before the speech was made, saying the Conservatives offered "only gimmicks, division and more of the same".

Addressing parliament at the opening of its new session, Labour leader Keir Starmer accused the Conservatives of using the speech to try to save their "own skin", describing it as a day "when it became crystal clear that the change Britain needs is from Tory (Conservative) decline to Labour renewal".

In the King's Speech, the government signalled it would move ahead with the Sentencing Bill that will bring forward tougher jail sentences for the most serious offenders, and repeated its pledge to boost economic growth and reduce inflation.

But, in a possible sign that calls from some Conservative lawmakers to offer voters tax cuts will go unheeded, the king said: "My ministers will address inflation and the drivers of low growth over demands for greater spending or borrowing."

阅读政府的一些气候政策可能会让查尔斯感到不舒服，他在环境问题上已经有 50 多年的竞选经验了。 The government has already moved to delay a ban on sales of new petrol cars, but officials have repeatedly said ministers were not giving up on the overall targets, just being more "pragmatic" in how they get there.

Sunak confirmed in an introduction to the speech he would bring in legislation to hold North Sea oil and gas licensing rounds annually - something Labour has ruled out - to help "the country to transition to net zero by 2050 without adding undue burdens on households".

That was one of only two new bills expected to be presented to the House of Commons this week, with the remainder being legislative plans rolled over from the previous parliament.

Sunak's government plans to phase out tobacco sales to young people in England and, in an attempt to win over younger voters, press ahead with reforms to the housing market, outlawing no-fault evictions for renters.

但苏纳克在赢回选民方面面临着一场艰苦的斗争，工党在民意调查中领先约 20 个百分点。 His party is mired in allegations of sex scandals, under scrutiny over its actions during the COVID-19 pandemic and deeply divided over its strategy before the next election.

他希望他的议程能够扭转局面。

"We have turned the corner over the last year and put the country on a better path," Sunak said in his introduction.

“但这些眼前的优先事项并不会限制我们的雄心壮志。它们只是我们计划的基础，为我们的子孙后代建设更美好的未来，并实现国家所需的变革。”

俄罗斯周二正式退出一项限制关键类别常规武装力量的具有里程碑意义的安全条约，并指责美国扩大北约军事联盟，破坏了冷战后的安全。

The 1990 Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe (CFE), signed a year after the fall of the Berlin Wall, placed verifiable limits on categories of conventional military equipment that NATO and the then-Warsaw Pact could deploy.

该条约旨在防止冷战双方集结力量在欧洲迅速进攻另一方，但在莫斯科不受欢迎，因为它削弱了苏联在常规武器方面的优势。

俄罗斯于 2007 年暂停参与该条约，并于 2015 年停止积极参与。在全面入侵乌克兰一年多后，俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京 (Vladimir Putin) 在 5 月签署了一项法令，谴责该条约。

俄罗斯外交部表示，俄罗斯已于午夜正式退出该条约，该条约现已成为“历史”。

“《欧洲常规武装力量条约》是在冷战结束时缔结的，当时基于合作的全球和欧洲安全新架构的形成似乎是可能的，并且做出了适当的尝试，”该部表示。

俄罗斯表示，美国推动北约扩大，导致联盟国家“公开规避”该条约的集团限制，并补充说，芬兰加入北约和瑞典加入北约意味着该条约已失效。

该部表示：“从俄罗斯根本安全利益的角度来看，即使是正式保留《通用军事条约》也变得不可接受。”并指出，美国及其盟国并未批准更新后的 1999 年《通用军事条约》。

乌克兰战争引发了莫斯科与西方关系自冷战深入以来最严重的危机。克里姆林宫发言人德米特里·佩斯科夫周末表示，与美国的关系低于零。

在俄罗斯宣布打算今年退出该条约后，北约谴责了这一决定，称其破坏了欧洲-大西洋安全。

“俄罗斯多年来一直没有遵守其 CFE 义务，” 北约 6 月表示。 “俄罗斯对乌克兰的侵略战争以及白俄罗斯的同谋，违背了《欧洲常规武装力量条约》的目标。”

美国及其盟国已将批准经修改的 1999 年《欧洲联盟公约》与俄罗斯履行对格鲁吉亚和摩尔多瓦的承诺联系起来。俄罗斯表示这种联系是错误的。

据美国国务院称，2011年，为了回应俄罗斯的“暂停”（华盛顿称该暂停根据该条约不合法），美国和北约停止了对俄罗斯的实施。

“俄罗斯自 2007 年以来‘暂停’执行该条约，严重损害了该条约的可核查性，降低了透明度，并破坏了二十多年来一直是北约与俄罗斯关系和欧洲安全核心要素的安全合作方式。”部门表示，2020年。
